headline: Amazing Pork Tenderloin in the Slow Cooker
description: This slow cooker pork tenderloin is so tender it will melt in your mouth! It's served with a red wine au jus flavored with garlic and soy sauce.

video.description: See how to make quick-and-easy pork tenderloin in your slow cooker.
video.name: Amazing Pork Tenderloin in the Slow Cooker

name: Amazing Pork Tenderloin in the Slow Cooker
recipeIngredient: 1 (1 ounce) envelope dry onion soup mix
freshly ground black pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Place pork tenderloin and soup mix in a slow cooker. Pour water, wine, and soy sauce on top, turning pork to coat. Carefully spread garlic over pork, leaving as much on top as possible. Sprinkle with pepper.
Cover and cook on Low for 4 hours or until the internal temperature reaches 145 degrees F (63 degrees C).
Remove pork from the slow cooker and let rest for 10 minutes. Slice and serve with cooking liquid on the side as au jus.

I did turn it up to high for the last half hour to three quarters of an hour. 

I think one thing I will do next time is punch some holes in the roast and let it marinate for an hour or more before putting in the crock pot. Just to get a little more flavor into the roast.

Soooo good! I made it twice in a week. I did add a beef bouillon cube and a few dashes of Worcester Sauce. The au jus was amazing, especially paired with mashed potatoes.

Made this slow cooker pork tenderloin for Easter. Very simple ingredients and easy to prep. Cooked on high for 4 hours since meat was refrigerator cold at the start of cooking. Meat was very tender, flavorful, and cooked thoroughly. Added some corn starch to the juices while the meat rested. Good gravy over mashed potatoes and as au jus for the meat. This turned out to be really good. I thought it was full of flavor (I used Better than Bullion instead of plain water), which might have punched it up. Before serving, I put the liquids on the stove and added cornstarch to thicken it up and that was delicious over mashed cauliflower. Easy to make, uses pantry staples, so this is a keeper.

This was delicious, though a tad salty (due to the onion mix). Adjusted the second time to use 1 c. red wine (whatever you have on hand - I've used a Montepulciano and Chianti, both were great!) and an additional half cup of water. I also added some diced fresh sweet onions the second time, and they softened nicely. Also, I strained the sauce and thickened with 2 Tbsp of cornstarch mixed with just enough water to dissolve and breakup clumps.
I didnt have the onion soup or minced garlic, so I use Au Jus and minced up about 5 garlic bulbs (probably wrong wording) . I added garlic salt and some Tony Chachere's.

This? This recipe turned out FANTASTIC. The first time I used a pork tenderloin, and just doubled the amounts of everything to make sure there was enough (we were expecting guests). The trick, I found, to making sure all the pork was tender was to chop it up into half-fist sized chunks. Due to oversight, a couple of ingredients were different - half of the red wine was Sangria, and half of the soy sauce was actually teriyaki sauce. 

The second time, I used a pork shoulder roast, carving off chunks of the meat and then just dropping the whole bone into the sauce to cook for the full time. Everything came out tender and moist and delicious all over. It was really easy to remove the meat left on the bone from it with just a fork, it was so tender.
I wouldn't change a thing - Yum!
